Main.TextENG: He regularly competed in national competitions, and he was popular around the school... Tomoe had vague memories of the time.

Main.TextJPN: 彼女が陸上部を辞めると決めたときも最後まで慰留してくれたり、退部後も親身になって相談に乗ってくれたりもした。
Main.TextENG: Even when she decided to quit the track team, he persuaded her to reconsider until the end. And even after she officially withdrew, they still stayed close and talked with each other.

Main.TextJPN: とはいえ、巴が茨城の大学に入学してからは疎遠になり、その後連絡も途絶えていたが…。
Main.TextENG: Nonetheless, they became separated after Tomoe entered Ibaraki University, and they lost contact...

Main.TextJPN: 「それにしても塚田先輩、今は何をやっておられるんですか？」
Main.TextENG: ``Anyway, what are you doing now, Tsukada-senpai?``

Main.TextJPN: 「俺か？@k@vS11/33/420800007.　ふっふっふっ、聞いて驚け。@k@vS11/33/420800008.実は今、とある代議士先生の秘書を勤めているのさ」
Main.TextENG: ``Me?@k@vS11/33/420800007. Fu fu fu, feast your ears on this.@k@vS11/33/420800008. Actually, I'm working as the secretary for a certain congressman.``

Main.TextJPN: 「とある、って…え？」
Main.TextENG: ``A certain... what?``

Main.TextJPN: そこで巴は、彼の手に持つチラシに目を向ける。そこには、さっきまで選挙カーの壇上で演説を行っていた千葉厚生大臣の顔があった。
Main.TextENG: Then, Tomoe looked at the flyers in his hand. And there, she saw the face of the Minister of Health and Welfare, Chiba, who was giving that speech on the election car just a moment ago.

Main.TextJPN: 「ひょっとして、この千葉厚生大臣の？」
Main.TextENG: ``Is it, perhaps, Minister Chiba?``

Main.TextJPN: 「あははは、その通り！@k@vS11/33/420800010.　この千葉先生の第二秘書ってわけだ。@k@vS11/33/420800011.といっても、こうやってビラ配りに精を出しているあたり、さまにはなっていないけどな」
Main.TextENG: ``Ahahaha, exactly!@k@vS11/33/420800010. I'm Chiba-sensei's second secretary.@k@vS11/33/420800011. Although, handing out flyers like this isn't what I signed up for.``

Main.TextJPN: 「そんなことないですよ。@k@vS11/28/420100331.カッコいいです、とっても」
Main.TextENG: ``Don't say that.@k@vS11/28/420100331. That's really cool.``

Main.TextJPN: 巴は本心から、そう答える。
Main.TextENG: Tomoe responded from the bottom of her heart.

Main.TextJPN: そういえば以前から、塚田は政治家になると公言して政経学部を目指していた。
Main.TextENG: Come to think of it, Tsukada did once say he was pursuing the department of political science and economics because he wanted to become a politician.

Main.TextJPN: 進学した大学も、確か国会議員を多く輩出している一流私大だった。
Main.TextENG: And the college he ended up attending was a high-ranking private university that has produced a lot of congress members in the past.

Main.TextJPN: 入学金が半端なく高くて、とても巴の通えるところではなかったが…。
Main.TextENG: But the enrollment fee was far higher than Tomoe could manage...

Main.TextJPN: 「夢に向かって頑張ってるんですね、すごいです。@k@vS11/28/420100333.この調子だと、議員先生になる日も近そうですね」
Main.TextENG: ``You're doing your best to pursue your dreams. That's amazing.@k@vS11/28/420100333. At the rate you're going, you'll be a legislator yourself before long.``

Main.TextJPN: 「あははは、それはまだまだ。@k@vS11/33/420800013.今はひたすら先生のかばん持ちとビラ配りで、勉強中さ！@k@vS11/33/420800014.　…ところで南井は今、何やってるんだ？」
Main.TextENG: ``Ahahaha, that's still a long ways out.@k@vS11/33/420800013. For now, I'm just carrying the boss's bags, passing out flyers, and studying!@k@vS11/33/420800014. ...By the way, Minai, what are you up to nowadays?``

Main.TextJPN: 「え、私は…」
一瞬、口ごもる。
Main.TextENG: She hesitated for a moment.

Main.TextJPN: なんとなく選挙演説に耳を傾けるたくさんの人だかりの中、『刑事です』とはおおっぴらに言う気にはなれなかった。
Main.TextENG: After listening to that whole campaign speech, somehow she couldn't bring herself to say, ``I'm a detective.``

Main.TextJPN: 「ちょっと今日は、出張で東京に出てきまして。@k@vS11/28/420100336.今は愛知の垣内ってところで働いています」
Main.TextENG: ``I'm in Tokyo today for a brief business trip.@k@vS11/28/420100336. Right now, I'm working in Kakiuchi, Aichi prefecture.``

Main.TextJPN: 「垣内？@k@vS11/33/420800016.　へー、そうなんだ。@k@vS11/33/420800017.千葉先生の地元からも近いんだな」
Main.TextENG: ``Kakiuchi?@k@vS11/33/420800016. Wow, I see.@k@vS11/33/420800017. That's close to Chiba-sensei's hometown.``

Main.TextJPN: 「えっ、…そうなんですか？」
Main.TextENG: ``Eh...? Really?``

Main.TextJPN: そういえば、町のどこかでその人のポスターを見かけたような気がする。
Main.TextENG: Come to think if it, she did seem to recall seeing him on a poster somewhere in town.

Main.TextJPN: しかし、厚生大臣を務めるほど偉い代議士さんとはさすがに思わなかった。
Main.TextENG: However, she didn't realize it was a congressman as important as the Minister of Health and Welfare.

Main.TextJPN: 「俺も、来年からは選挙活動でお国入りする予定だから、ひょっとしたらどこかで会えるかもな、…なーんて。@k@vS11/33/420800019.もし会えたら、今度は飯でも食おうぜ」
Main.TextENG: ``I'm scheduled to head to that area for next year's campaign, so maybe we can meet up somewhere... What do you say?@k@vS11/33/420800019. If we meet up, let's have a meal next time.``

Main.TextJPN: 「…相変わらずですね、先輩は」
Main.TextENG: ``...You're the same as ever, senpai.``

Main.TextJPN: 「あはははは、相変わらずなのはお前の方だよ。@k@vS11/33/420800021.スーツ姿で遠くから見ても、すぐにわかったしさ」
Main.TextENG: ``Ahahahaha, if anyone is the same as ever, it's you.@k@vS11/33/420800021. Even though you were wearing a suit and at a distance, I recognized you immediately.``

Main.TextJPN: そこへ、少し離れたところから『塚田さーん』と声がかかる。その声の主に返事を送ってから、塚田は内ポケットから名刺入れを取り出した。
Main.TextENG: Then, a voice came from a short distance away shouting, ``Tsukada-saaan.`` Tsukada quickly responded to that call, then reached into his pocket and pulled out a business card holder.

Main.TextJPN: 「悪いな。俺、この後用事があるから。@k@vS11/33/420800023.あ、これ俺の名刺。@k@vS11/33/420800024.もしよかったら、暇なときにでも連絡してくれよ」
Main.TextENG: ``Sorry, I have business to attend to after this.@k@vS11/33/420800023. Oh, here's my business card.@k@vS11/33/420800024. If you'd like, feel free to contact me in your spare time.``

Main.TextJPN: そう言って塚田は巴の手に名刺を握らせると、足早に去っていく。
Main.TextENG: Tsukada placed the business card into Tomoe's hand as he said that, then quickly walked off.

Main.TextJPN: その背中は、あっという間に人ごみの中に飲み込まれて見えなくなった。
Main.TextENG: Then, his back was swallowed by the crowd in the blink of an eye.

Main.TextJPN: 「変わらない、か…」
Main.TextENG: ``Haven't changed at all, huh...?``

Main.TextJPN: おそらく何の含みもなく言った、ただの社交辞令だろう。
Main.TextENG: That was probably just social etiquette, without any special meaning.

Main.TextJPN: だけど。
Main.TextENG: However,

Main.TextJPN: 今の巴には、まるで過去から前に進むことができていない自分への中傷にも聞こえて、…ちくりと、胸が痛んだ。
Main.TextENG: At this particular moment, Tomoe felt like it was admonishing her for her inability to move on from the past... and her chest began to ache.

Main.TextJPN: 「…あ、おばあぢゃん？@k@vS11/28/420100343.　うん、うん…んだよ、今上野駅出だどこ。@k@vS11/28/420100344.仕事終わったがら、これからそっちさ向かうどごろだっぺ」
Main.TextENG: ``...Ah, Grandma?@k@vS11/28/420100343. Yeah, yeah... That's right, I'm leaving Ueno Station now.@k@vS11/28/420100344. My work is complete, so I'll be heading over shortly.``

Main.TextJPN: 「え？　…うん、んだね。@k@vS11/28/420100346.特急乗っかり継いで行くがら、着くのは十時くれえだっぺが」
Main.TextENG: ``Huh? ...Yeah, right.@k@vS11/28/420100346. I'm taking the express train, so I'll arrive around 10 o'clock.``

Main.TextJPN: 「あはは、大丈夫だね。@k@vS11/28/420100348.もう子供じゃねえんだがら。@k@vS11/28/420100349.鍵持ってるがら、先ぃ寝てでよ。…そんじゃ」
Main.TextENG: ``Ahaha, I'll be fine.@k@vS11/28/420100348. I'm not a child anymore.@k@vS11/28/420100349. I have a key, so you can head to bed early. ...Anyway, later.``

Main.TextJPN: 公衆電話に受話器を置いて、巴はざらざらと出てきた残りの十円玉を取ってポケットにしまう。@kそして振り返ると同時に、駅の構内のアナウンスが列車の到着を告げた。
Main.TextENG: After hanging up the receiver on the public phone, Tomoe grabbed the remaining 10 yen coin from the coin return and put it in her pocket.@k And just as she turned around, an announcement came out that the train was arriving at the station.

Main.TextJPN: 連休とはいえ遅い時間のためか、車内にはほとんど人の姿がなかった。
Main.TextENG: Though it was a holiday, there weren't a lot of people in the car, perhaps because of the late hour.

Main.TextJPN: 「…ふぅ」
窓際の指定席に座って、荷物を隣の席に置く。
Main.TextENG: She sat down at her designated seat by the window, and set her bag down on the seat next to her.

Main.TextJPN: そして人心地ついてから背もたれに身体を預け、駅の売店で買ったタブロイド誌を広げた。
Main.TextENG: Then, she leaned back against the backrest to get comfortable and spread open the tabloid she bought at the station shop.

Main.TextJPN: 開いたそのページに、さっき演説をしていた千葉厚相の写真が映っている。
Main.TextENG: The page she opened to had a picture of Minister Chiba, who was giving that speech earlier.

Main.TextJPN: 見出しには大きく、『医療改革を推進・高齢者向けの負担軽減策を提案』と書いてあった。
Main.TextENG: A massive headline was written next to the picture, saying: ``Promoting Medical Reform. Proposing Measures to Reduce Burden on Elderly.``

Main.TextJPN: （こんなに有名な先生なら、先輩が『先生サマ』になる日も近いかもね）
Main.TextENG: (If he's really such a famous legislator, then maybe it won't be long at all before senpai becomes a ``legislator`` himself.)

Main.TextJPN: ただ、もはや塚田にはもう、それ以上の感情は持っていない。
Main.TextENG: But beyond that, she no longer had any feelings for Tsukada.

Main.TextJPN: 久しぶりに会った彼は相変わらずで、…そして、別れたあの日の印象のままだった。
Main.TextENG: Seeing him for the first time in a while, and seeing he was just the same as always... reminded her of the day they broke up.
``...@k@vS11/28/420100354.Oh, it's already time for the GI race, huh?``

Main.TextJPN: 気分を変えるつもりでめくった真ん中の見開き紙面に競馬の馬柱表を見つけて、巴はそこだけを抜き取る。
Main.TextENG: Intending to change the mood, Tomoe looked down on the page in front of her and saw a column about horse racing.

Main.TextJPN: 賭け事はあまり好きではないが、競馬だけは暇潰しと年配の人たちとの話題づくりにと、なんとなく若いときから続けていた。
Main.TextENG: She wasn't very fond of gambling, but she did follow horse racing since she was young, both as a way to kill time and to have a topic to discuss with elderly people.

Main.TextJPN: 実際、クロスワードと同じ感覚で気ままに予想を立てていると、それだけで１時間は退屈せずに過ごすことができる。
Main.TextENG: In fact, making carefree predictions about the outcome can kill an hour just as well as a crossword puzzle, without any boredom.

Main.TextJPN: だからこれは、夕刊紙の最後の楽しみでもあった。
Main.TextENG: So, it was the last thing she looked forward to from the evening paper.

Main.TextJPN: 「ま、しばらくは京都開催だから、中山は空いてるだろうし。@k@vS11/28/420100356.明日馬券買いに行ってもいいかな。……え？」
Main.TextENG: ``Well, they've been holding it in Kyoto for a while now, so Nakayama shouldn't be very crowded.@k@vS11/28/420100356. I wonder if I can buy some tickets tomorrow. ...Huh?``

Main.TextJPN: その時。
Main.TextENG: Just then.

Main.TextJPN: 何気なくめくった社会面の小さな記事を見た瞬間、…巴の頭の中から全てのことが消えて真っ白になる。
Main.TextENG: The moment Tomoe turned the page and casually noticed a local news article... all thoughts completely vanished from Tomoe's mind.
``It can't be...?!``

Main.TextJPN: そこに書かれていたのは、…とある地方病院で起こった、患者の転落事故の話。
Main.TextENG: What was written there... was the story of a patient who fell from a local hospital.

Main.TextJPN: しかし、その事故で死亡した患者の名前は忘れもしない、…彼女が以前に聞き込みを行った、『女生徒校内傷害事件』の被害者の男子生徒だったのだ。
Main.TextENG: However, the name of the patient who died in the accident was one she would never forget... It was a boy she had interviewed before, a victim of the ``schoolgirl campus assault`` incident.
